column1: I am a man with DID and I found this book insulting to those who truly suffer from its effects.  The book was written with an attempt to read like a novel.  The author obviously fills in many trivial events with specluations.  Since the Mr. West was NOT co-conscious for much of the book
column2: he fills in the missing details with fluff and extremely poor writing.  The book is easy to read since it was written on a 5th grade level.  My eleven year old could easily sit down and read this.  The constant swearing and profanity left me baffled as to why the author decided to insert offensive language.  It didn't further the plot or define himself.  If it was an attempt to show the reader that he was a tough guy dealing with DID
column3: it missed the mark since he spends most of the book refusing to take any responsibility for his actions
column4: his family
column5: and his diagnosis of DID.  The author spends most of his energy attempting to create a gripping story around his DID which falls flat in many of its 300 pages.  Not only are his sessions not realistic
column6: but he paints his DID as debilitating deciding that he cannot work or take care of his family or even his young son.  The wife decides to work and puts the son in day care so that the father does not have to do anything but lay around with a blanket and toys and moan.  In truth
column7: people with DID get up in the morning
column8: dress
column9: go to work
column10: make dinner
column11: help with homework
column12: fix the plumbing
column13: etc.  This is not an accurate portrayal of someone with DID.  Life with DID is hard and devastating
column14: but DID is not an excuse to quit life.  Instead
column15: all of life's responsibilities actually helps the person with DID to be in the present.    I found the therapy techniques in this book more consistent with DID therapy than in Fractured Mind.  However
column16: Mr. West was not able to find a therapist who gave him the dose of reality that he needed until the last few chapters. The first therapist never encouraged Mr. West to be present or taught him the skills he needed to be present and function as an adult.  This obviously gave Mr. West the green light to whine and whimper through most of the book.  At the end of the book I became very concerned about Mr. West entering the field of psychology and leading others down the his distorted path of healing.  In short
column17: I find the book poorly written with a great amount of offensive language
column18: a contrived storyline with an abundance of holes
column19: and an inaccurate portayal of someone who struggles with DID.  I am concerned that readers of this book will assume that there is important information within the pages that will help them. It will only assist the reader in becoming more confused about the disorder.   The Dissociative Identity Disorder Source Book is still the best book that will help anyone learn about what DID is and how to deal with it.  Energies should be spent reading viable material that will explain
column20: teach and help those with DID and their support. Please do not get sucked in by the media hype and the over effulgent swooning of others who obviously have dealt very little with DID. For respect of those who daily brave the storm of DID
column21: do NOT buy this book.  You've been warned.

column1: There is some very helpful information in here about how a woman's cycle works. I would be very cautious
column2: however
column3: about the nutrition information. Here is my story:  I was ovulating every 16-18 days with a 11-day luteal phase. Hoping to ovulate closer to every 14 days and lengthen my luteal phase
column4: I began taking the vitamin Optivite
column5: so heavily recommended in the book. I took Optivite for four months
column6: and in that time I would either ovulate extremely late--30+ days followed by a 9 or 10 day luteal cycle-- or NOT AT ALL.   For whatever reason
column7: I didn't immediately connect my ovulation problems with taking the Optivite (seems so obvious now). Then I read something from another source about how excess vitamin A can inhibit ovulation. I then QUIT taking Optivite. My first cycle off of Optivite
column8: my ovulation returned to normal-- and THAT IS WHEN I FINALLY GOT PREGNANT.  It may be that Optivite has helped other women who were really deficient in some of those vitamins. But
column9: in my case
column10: I guess I was healthy to begin with
column11: and it just screwed with my body

column1: The book's jacket announces somewhat presumptuously: "students on campus tell you what you really want to know."   My kids are interested in pre-med and business.  My neighbor's kid is interested in pre-law.  Clearly the Yale Daily News Staff assumes we don't want to know about the average scores undergraduates make on the standardized tests they take in college.  Yet
column2: a high school kid thinking ahead to professional schooling might well want to know how students do on the MCAT
column3: GMAT or LSAT tests at different colleges.  Just like the undergrad schools that use SAT scores as one factor in their admissions process
column4: high school students could use this later college test information as one factor in their choice of schools.  But high school students are out of luck.  These data aren't included in the Common Data Set
column5: and the Yale Daily News Staff doesn't ask for them.   The Yale Daily News Staff also assumes that we don't want any hard data about campus crime.  They ignore completely the information that colleges must make publicly available under the Clery Act.   Instead we get chirpy PR snippets such as that reported for the University of Pennsylvania: "Some students are concerned for their safety in the local community
column6: but most people agree that safety in the area has 'really improved recently'." They deftly duck the issue of just how bad safety was before and what today's crime numbers are.  It's just another don't-rock-the-boat and somewhat lazy effort by a college guidebook publisher

column1: This encyclopedia is for true believers in the Post Keynesian tradition of Joan Robinson
column2: G L S Shackle and Paul Davidson.Unfortunately
column3: this approach to economics can't operationalize any of the analytic tools and concepts Keynes developed in  the A Treatise on Probability in 1921(TP)or in the General Theory in 1936(GT).An obvious place to start is the failure of Post Keynesians to operationalize Keynes's concepts of the weight of the evidence in the TP
column4: uncertainty in the GT and probability in both the TP and GT.Keynesian probability is fundamentally of an interval nature.It is quantitative and at the same time noncomparative
column5: nonrankable
column6: and incommensurable if any of the interval estimates overlap.The source of this analysis is chapters 15
column9: and 22 of the TP.Weight of the evidence
column10: w
column11: is an index that measures the completeness of the relevant
column12: potential
column13: available evidence upon which probability estimates will be based.Keynes defined it as 0<=w<=1.If w=0
column14: then you are dealing with what Keynes called ignorance in the TP.A w=0 would also hold in the 1937 Quarterly Journal of Economics article if"We simply do not know!"Other names would be complete or total uncertainty or the fundamental uncertainty of the Shackles and the Davidsons.w's between 0 and 1 represent cases of partial knowledge and partial ignorance.Here a set of different probability distributions or a set of intervals would have to be constructed.A w=1 allows a decision maker to specify a single unique probability distribution or interval.Given a strict application of the central limit theorem and the law of large numbers
column15: suppose that the data passed the Lexis Q-test for stability.Keynes would then agree that one could apply a normal probability distribution since an analysis of the data would support such a conclusion as long as the data was homogeneous in its composition throughout the series or sequence.Now let us turn to the GT.Keynes was quite clear that uncertainty is a function of the weight of the evidence.As the weight of the evidence increases
column16: uncertainty decreases.As the weight of the evidence decreases
column17: uncertainty increases.u=f(w).If w=0
column18: then uncertainty is total and no estimates of probability are possible.In this case

column3: the 17th of March

column5: please enjoy the story and do not rely on the facts.   Speaking as a professor of early European history for 18 years

column1: The book poses a very good question
column2: one that most people are thinking about - "What will the future of work be in an outsourced global environment? "  But sadly Malone never risks making any futuristic predictions. This book captures the history of functional organizations and a some recent radical organizational models.    Internal trading concept for sharing scarce resources within an organization was rather interesting. In the final chapters Malone goes in-depth about the consulting industry's model of resource deployment
column3: but he seemed to have missed out the key role that Resource Deployment Managers play in serving customers. As an earlier reviewer mentioned the concepts are over simplified and repetitive. It was an interesting read for me until I finished 2/3rd of the book
column4: when I started to slowly discover that the book was repeating concepts and the author is reluctant to be making bold predictions as the title suggested. If you just want an interesting presentation on different organization models currently in practice then this book may be for you but if you are looking beyond the present then you will be disappointed.

column1: It's not easy to criticize this book
column2: because it is beautifully written and captures something tragic and poignant and important:  the emotional trials and conflicts of a spunky twelve year old girl who is coming of age in a world that doesn't understand her.  But McCullers' darker undercurrents taint the book.  Threaded throughout are elements of sexual perversity
column3: terrible sexual boundaries with children
column4: and hints at pedophilia
column5: leading me to question strongly what in the world happened to Carson McCullers when she was a little girl.  Furthermore
column6: the perversity often pops up in a disjointed way that adds nothing to the book's power
column7: and thus reads largely as gratuitous.  A few examples from the book - a book which I did not finish because I didn't trust where its author was taking me:  1) The main character
column8: a pubescent twelve year old girl who is nearly five-foot six
column9: has spent her whole life up till now sleeping in the bed with her widowed and single father
column10: until he looks at her one day and realizes she's "a great big long-legged twelve year old" - McCullers leaves exactly what he means to our imagination - and kicks her out of bed.  2) The girl's best friend is a six year old boy
column11: whom she bullies and torments
column12: and then basically forces to spend the night with her in her bed.  McCullers makes a point of showing how they change their clothes for bed in the same room - "with their backs turned to each other" - and then get in bed together.  Once the little boy is asleep the girl
column13: who is two months away from turning thirteen
column14: rubs his bare stomach with her hand
column15: licks him behind his ear
column16: and then nuzzles up to him.  (Also
column17: imagine if their genders were reversed!)  3) The father takes a married couple as boarders in the house
column18: but the girl - then age nine - walks in on them doing something overtly sexual with the door left purposefully open.  McCullers leaves it to the readers' imagination what her little protagonist viewed.  4) McCullers talks about the girl character
column19: age twelve
column20: having had sex with a neighborhood boy.  Again
column21: she gets vague on details
column22: but why is she sharing even this much?  If you were to remove the literary style and add a scant few more details
column23: you would have child pornography.  5) Eventually the girl changes her name
column24: wears an adult dress that makes her look much older - and goes out on the town and meets a visiting adult soldier.  He comes onto her sexually - though stops only because others come into the bar where he is giving her alcohol.  One is only left to wonder where the book will go from here.  Because this book was written in the 1940s the author can get away with it - and perhaps also because she's a female author - but really
column25: it's disturbing and perverse

column1: I was really excited about this book when I first heard about it. I'd read through River God a few times
column2: and I was eagerly awaiting a follow up... And I wouldn't really consider The Seventh Scroll to be a follow up
column3: but rather an Indiana Jones type story that holds some references to the characters in River god.   I already felt let down and confused after the first 20 pages of Warlock. Something innate and compelling that permeated the world of River God was completely gone. The writing seemed uncharacteristically dull and rushed.   Maybe it's something to do with the way the narrative was changed from the first person to the third. There was something intimate about the reader's relationship to Taita's thoughts in River God. The story alerted you to his flaws and arrogance by letting you listen to him brag and congratulate himself. In this novel
column4: Taita is a bland and uninspired figure.   I find it difficult to even recall the plot of Warlock. The characters were all 2-Dimensional and devoid of personality. If it weren't for the token Wilbur Smith gore and sex
column5: this book would almost play out like a children's version of River God.   In some ways this book disgraces the world that he created and brought to life with River God. It is impossible not to make the comparison
column6: and while it is an easy book to go through
column7: nothing in this one stuck for me. I was bored instead of fascinated.   I actually found that by the end of the book
column8: I was trying to discount it and just forget about it
column9: so that it would not taint my attatchment to River God. In every way that River God was epic and inspired
column10: this novel is boring and predictable.   If it were possible to detatch it from the first book and enjoy it for what it is (a silly action adventure novel about ancient Egyapt)
column11: I might give it 3 stars... but it is absolutely impossible to do so
column12: and in some ways I almost regret reading it.

column7: ranging from  surreal
column8: to tragic
column9: to tongue in cheek
column10: to implausible (with the widow dancing and smiling shortly after she had witnessed losing her entire family to a massacre?) made it difficult at last to gain an emotional foothold and invest

column13: seemed rather far fetched and silly
column14: moreso with the minister commanding something more akin to a Broadway theatrical stage presence than a real person might portray given the strain of the times. Renee' Zelwegger did well but proved unbelievable for me in light of her typecasting and excellent role in Jerry MacGuire. Nicole Kidman was not in her element
column15: yet even here in the role of a helpless swooner her acting credentials were present. This film was over-starred and substantially miscast. Didn't need Donald as Kidman's father and Kidman and Zellwegger's tension between themselves proved more distracting than complimentary. Overall the movie was interesting but lengthy to a fault. Undeniably a remarkable collaborative brainfest that in several ways might have been greatly improved.

column1: This book came out at the same time that Judith Miller was doing the incredibly bad reporting for the NYTimes that lead the US into the Iraq War. Much of her reporting on WMD spurred interest in her book and increased its sales. I wonder how much her incredibly bad reporting that the Times has now repudiated as false and misleading can be credited to unconscious credulousness centered on the knowledge that more WMD fear would increase her book sales

column12: the supposed antagonist

column14: she's unlikable just like the rest of the characters.  Overall
column15: I suggest you avoid this book if at all possible. It's a loppy book with no real purpose or message.

column1: This is truly a disappointing book.  It starts incredibly slowly and I found it very hard to become interested in the plot.  Another disappointment is Koontz's recycling of elements from other novels: (1) plucky
column2: highly intelligent disabled girl (the young female protagonist in "The Hideaway" had almost identical deformities and personality)
column3: (2) devoted
column4: super-powered canine companions
column5: (3) bad guys driving around in ultra pimped-out RVs
column6: and (4) evil bioethicists.  The Leilani character is patently ridiculous.  She conveniently has a genius IQ
column7: but that does not make the absurdly adult manner in which she speaks any more believable.  I found it so disconcerting as to detract from the plot.  Koontz clearly has trouble writing for children
column8: and this book is no exception.  Almost all the children featured in his books are either autistic/MR or genius wunderkinds; the latter
column9: however
column10: does not justify his habit of making smart children talk like genius adults.  Dean heaps the hardships on poor Leilani
column11: with all the subtlety of an episode of Walker
column12: Texas Ranger.  In case you miss the anvils
column13: you are supposed to really
column14: really like her and fear for her safety.  I don't know how or where Dean Koontz learned about bioethics
column15: but he has a terribly misguided view of the field
column16: taking an extreme sect of it to represent the main viewpoint of the field.  Further
column17: he states multiple times that these eugenic bioethics principles are being taught to medical students at major universities (who will have to pay for their involvement with evil bioethics) -- as a medical student
column18: I can assure you that this is patently untrue.  That Koontz could be so off-base on a topic that directly relates to the central motive is disconcerting and makes an already weak book even harder to swallow.  The final issue is Koontz's near-deification of dogs
column19: particularly Golden Retrievers
column20: which is a common motif in his more recent works.  It is ridiculous and unintentionally funny to an almost painful degree.  His obsession with dogs and their mystical powers borders on the psychotic (and I like dogs).  This novel probably features the most egregious example of Koontz's tendency to create overly sappy
column21: sugary-sweet endings.  Dean Koontz has written many books better than this one.  Spend your money on one of his stronger efforts

column1: A major shortcoming of Bazerman and Watkins' book is the failure to provide adequate evidence to support their arguments about what they call "predictable surprises"
column2: which they define as "an event or series of events that take an individual or group by surprise
column3: despite prior awareness of all of the information necessary to anticipate the events and their consequences." Bazerman and Watkins build their case substantially on just two examples: aviation security failures leading to the terrorist attacks of September 11
column4: 2001 and auditor independence concerns leading to the collapse of Enron and Arthur Anderson. Several other examples are discussed in less depth throughout the text
column5: however many of these are not actually predictable surprises under the definition provided. For example
column6: global warming is discussed a number of times; however global warming has been in public discussion since the 1930s
column7: and today a substantial majority of people believe not only the concept of global warming but that current warming is man-made. By 2050
column8: this subject will have been under study for 120 years and popular consensus will have been achieved for 50-60 years. This is certainly predictable
column9: but hardly a surprise. The United States' looming crisis in entitlement spending also falls in this category.  Flaws exist in other anecdotal support as well. For example
column10: Bazerman and Watkins cite aviation security failures as an occasion when overly discounting the future lead to a predictable surprise. Quick calculation based on figures provided in the book show that
column11: using equal discount rates for the expected future cost of security and the future cost of disaster
column12: even with a disaster probability as high as 10% for any given year
column13: the airlines would be ahead on a cost basis. The total destruction of both World Trade Center towers and the massive ensuing death toll was not reasonably foreseeable by the airline industry; based on the typical passenger plan carrying 78 people
column14: this was the equivalent of an absurd 41 simultaneous aircraft disasters! Given the cost of implementation and the low probability of such a large disaster
column15: even at a full cost of nearly $50 billion
column16: the airlines' decision to oppose security measures on a cost basis was reasonable. The full scope of this surprise was unlikely enough that it should not be termed "predictable."  Despite some good analysis of reasons predictable surprises occur and ways to avoid them
column17: this book is critically weakened by its lack of evidence. Bazerman and Watkins try to make it stand largely on just the aviation security and auditor independence failures; however these are insufficient evidence for their broad analysis and conclusions
column18: particularly given the weakness of those arguments provided. This book would be substantially more persuasive with more anecdotal support

column1: As an exercise in indulging the post-modern reader's understanding of William Shakespeare and the Early Modern Imagination
column2: this book provides an excellent meditation by a man who has spent many years with the artifacts (plays and poems) of another man. Stephen Greenblatt's contribution to Shakespeare studies and his methodology for researching Early Modern literature certainly ought to be noted and applauded. At the very least
column3: Professor Greenblatt indeed should share his own thoughts
column4: meditations
column5: and suppositions on the life of William Shakespeare. The matter of BIOGRAPHY
column6: however
column7: is an entirely separate issue. Greenblatt does not exactly name "The Will in the World" a biography
column8: but plenty of readers and scholars (and Amazon.com) have erroneously recognized it as such. Accepting this book as anything other than  critical Shakespearean mysticism (rather than all-out Bardoloatry) should be dismissed as fallacious
column9: deceptive
column10: and misleading. Be wary readers of anyone who stretches 16 pieces of documentary evidence (all posterity can claim for the life of William Shakespeare) into a book-length "study." If you seek the mythology
column11: then this book is for you; If you seek BIOGRAPHY
column12: I suggest S. Schoenbaum's "William Shakespeare: A Documentary Life."

column1: I was surprised to find this book on the shelf of books recommended for high-school students at my local bookstore
column2: but the subject intrigued me
column3: so I decided to take a chance on it. Like all decent sex manuals
column4: it gives  good advice in many matters -- foreplay
column5: treating one's partner with  respect
column6: and so forth
column7: but often lacks the detail necessary for one who  actually needs the advice in the first place to follow. And like most sex  manuals
column8: the people who need it the most are the ones who will be the least  likely to bother with it. There is a long catalog of various names of the  sex organs of both males and females which was half-amusing
column9: half-tedious.  Suffice to say that they are not all that different from the ones in use  today. Also
column10: certain idiotic misconceptions abound
column11: which will probably not  be helpful to most people -- that in order to satisfy a woman
column12: for example
column13: a man should be rich and have a penis roughly a foot long. Also
column14: certain  cultural assumptions are made which may strike some readers as odd
column15: but  which in fact are very telling -- for example
column16: in the period and location  when this book was written
column17: fat women were considered very erotic. Hearing  a man tall about how he adores his wife's double-chin is rather amusing (in  this sense it makes a good introductory study towards ideals of beauty as  one finds in Wolf's "The Beauty Myth")
column18: and lets one see that  contemporary idea of beauty are not by any means universal. Another  interesting aspect of the book was the notion that sex is an important and  decent part of one's life as it is given one by god. The author was  obviously Islamic and this shows over and over again
column19: but unlike in  Christian writings of the same period
column20: sex is portrayed as something  beautiful to be shared as a gift from heaven and not as a "dirty  secret". This is really quite refreshing -- in the west
column21: we still  suffer from this lamentable malady today. The Sheik also takes it for  granted that women enjoy sex as much as men
column22: and places a strong emphasis  on female satisfaction; something that only recently has become  fashionable. On the negative side
column23: the chapters on beastiality and  tribadism were left out in Burton's translation -- necessary considering  the time in which he lived
column24: but an omission which nevertheless leaves the  book incomplete. As a study in cultural values
column25: it is quite interesting
column26: as  a sex manual
column27: it is obviously dated and could use much improvement --  modern ones are much better. Depending on what you are looking for
column28: it may  be an interesting read
column29: but still comes across as rather dull; it won't  replace the Kama Sutra anytime soon

column1: I bought this puzzle for my kid after he solved the original cube.  I had read the review here and other places stating that one needed to be cautious when turning the puzzle.  However
column2: our major problem with it was that the orange stickers (within ten minutes of playing with the cube) began to peel back and fall off.  We tried using glue (they had no stick to them) to put them back but it was not long after that the green stickers began curling back and falling off as well.  The major problem is that these turned out not to be "stickers" after all
column3: but rather colored squares of vinyl adhereing to additional stickers beneath (all white) by means of static.  They fall off easily.  This is a nice puzzle for show (impressive on the desk) but not for actual continued use.  Hopefully
column4: Rubik's can use proper stickers or adhesive in the future and maybe even tighten up the design so that this can be used as a fun puzzle

column1: An Autobiography of Jack Gantos told under the name of Joey Pigza. While Jack Gantos sits in his jail cell he tells you the story of how he got there. Young Jack wants to be a writer
column2: but growing up in a poor family means that he doesn't have the money to go to school. So he goes to live with his grandparents in the Virgin Islands. Shortly discovering how much Jack drinks
column3: they kick him out. 	From there
column4: he goes to live with a family who have an extra room and he messes that up too when he gets sick all over their house. After going through that and a ghetto hotel
column5: he goes home to St Croix to live with his parents and work with his dad. He makes minimum wage by making and shipping crates. column1: In a historical novel
column2: I look for immersion in another place and time
column3: and involvement with characters that I can care about. For me
column4: Trent has not succeeded in either of these areas.  Although the author has a good grasp of our sketchy historical knowledge of the events in Alexandria in the early fifth century
column5: I don't get the sense that he has done much research on the broader history of this fascinating time -- to say nothing of the geography. The basics are all in place: the brilliant philosopher Hypatia
column6: the Great Library
column7: the religious turmoil
column8: the tension between church and state. But there's little in the way of detail to give you the sense of being there
column9: and as often as not the detail is wrong. For example
column10: the desert ascetics did not wear brown (the pagan sources are full of vilification of black-robed monks). Governors and bishops travelled in carriages with large retinues
column11: not alone in chariots like characters from "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum." (The "chariot" used by Hypatia is more likely to have been something like a sulky.) And no one ever met a woman by being asked to dance
column12: because the Romans did not engage in social dancing. As for the geography
column13: I'm still trying to figure out how you can get a view of the Nile from the western wall of Alexandria
column14: which itself lies west of the delta -- and Antioch was certainly not in Persia!  Trent's writing is fluid enough
column15: and occasionally there's a vivid and memorable image
column16: but he has a poor ear for diction and often chooses words that are jarring or even incorrect. For instance
column17: from a scene where a minor character visits her husband's grave: "She descended the broken steps to the fence. _What am I doing?_ she screamed." (The underscores signify italics
column18: which the author uses for characters' thoughts.) "Screamed" hardly seems the word to express inner doubts
column19: but it's typical of the clumsy way in which Trent tries to inject life into his characters.  Indeed
column20: we spend far too much time in the heads of the characters as they verbalize their thoughts and feelings. Not only does this fail to bring them to life (it mostly just makes them annoying); it also slows the pace of the action to a crawl.  Hypatia herself is an uneasy mixture of intellectual
column21: political
column22: and emotional ingredients that never coalesce into a character we can care deeply about. Indeed
column23: the book as a whole never makes up its mind whether it's a novel of ideas or a romance
column24: as the perspective shifts between the major players  discussing philosophy
column25: religion
column26: and politics
column27: and various love affairs or infatuations.   Many of the problems of this book could have been cleared up by a good editing
column28: but as is too often the case these days
column29: that stage of production seems to have been skipped. (How else would we see "palate" for "palette" and "reigns" for "reins"?) As it is
column30: we have an ambitious effort by someone who simply lacks the writing skills to carry it off.

column1: Half paean to old-time radio
column2: half murder mystery
column3: this overly melodramatic WWII-era set novel lurches along for far too long before petering out
column4: exhausted with itself. I've enjoyed Dunning's "Bookman" series
column5: and I like historically set mysteries
column6: so picking this up seemed like a no-brainer. But Dunning overextends himself with this one. The story revolves around Jack Dulaney
column7: a down-and-out racetrack horse-walker who gets in a fight that lands him in jail. His buddy helps to spring him from a work gang
column8: but is then killed. This is the catalyst for Jack's incredibly complicated search for the killer and reason behind the murder. The trail leads him to a New Jersey beach town and the radio station where his buddy used to work as an actor. There
column9: further disappearances and deaths are revealed
column10: including that of Carnahan
column11: the father of the woman he pined for years before. As it happens
column12: the woman is also in town
column13: working as a nightclub singer under an assumed name. Jack manages to get work at the station as a writer
column14: allowing him to poke around and try to get to the bottom of everything (not to mention rekindle his old flame).   Here is where the book starts to have real problems. Namely
column15: all the detail about old-time radio production is far more fascinating than the murders. I'm not particularly (nor are most readers likely to be) interested in how dramatic radio shows were put together back in the '30s and '40s
column16: but Dunning makes the station come alive and does a fascinating job of detailing the inner workings. From the scripting
column17: to the management
column18: the actors
column19: the sound effects
column20: it's all very well dramatized. So much so
column21: in fact
column22: that it's hard for the reader to care very much about the deaths of some characters met only very briefly or in flashbacks. The station's attempt to create original dramatic programming that pushed the limits of what was considered acceptable material--such as a scripted serial about black Americans
column23: an anti-war prison camp series
column24: and soforth--ends up being much more interesting. Unfortunately
column25: the story eventually leaves the radio setting (via a lame piece of misdirection lifted from Hamlet) to dive into the world of German spies in America
column26: the Irish Republic Army
column27: and all manner of melodrama.  The melodrama is enhanced by a certain thinness to the characters. The protagonist is an especially poorly drawn hero figure with altogether too keen a resemblance to the hero of Dunning's "Bookman" series. He's one of those all-purpose strong
column28: capable men. Street-fighting? No problem. Writing a critically well-received Steinbeck/Dos Passosesque novel? No problem. Escaping a work gang? No problem. Master writing radio drama overnight? No problem. Expert tracking through the woods? No problem. When the hero of a story turns out to be exceptional at everything
column29: the whole story is diluted. Beyond Jack
column30: the cast of characters is so large that Dunning doesn't really have the time or space to develop any of them in any meaningful way. It's not generally a good thing when the villain in a mystery is a character you can barely remember being in the story. This is a pity
column31: because there are a number of characters with potential
column32: and the old-time radio setting is certainly well done. As a historical novel about a small group of people striving in a creative field
column33: it works fairly well--in no small part due to the subsequent total demise of the world depicted in the book. Just don't expect to pick this up and find yourself immersed in a thriller.

column12: and Us

column1: Recently I got into a conversation with the guy next to me on the plane about some of the memorable books we had each read in the past few years.  Unfortunately
column2: I had to recall `Confidence'-easily the worst book I've read in years.  To describe it as disappointing is to go easy on Ms. Kanter.  It is far beyond that
column3: and altogether abominable and embarrassing.  That such a prestigious business school like Harvard can tenure a professor who writes such insipid pablum boggles the mind.  Let's start with the central (and only) idea of the book--that winning begets winning and losing begets losing.  This of course strikes most people as fairly straightforward and unworthy of a book's worth of elaboration.  Yet Ms. Kanter tumbles all over herself to spell out the details: why this is the case (as if someone with an ounce of inferential ability couldn't figure it out in a couple of minutes)
column4: how it affects team morale
column5: how it self-perpetuates
column6: etc...  And worst of all
column7: endless
column8: endless
column9: endless examples that do nothing or very little to elucidate; rather
column10: they simply restate what has just been said.  And they restate and restate and restate.  Tautological (I think the word was invented in anticipation of this book)
column11: boring
column12: tedious
column13: insipid
column14: stupid
column15: unthoughtful
column16: unenergetic
column17: disengaged
column18: disrespectful.  All these adjectives apply forcefully to the book.  Most of all
column19: though
column20: it is utterly uninventive and cliched.  Turn to any page and you'll find such gems of penetrating insight as (forgive me
column21: but these are so funny I have to quote at length):   "Winning feels good
column22: and good moods are contagious.  Success makes it easier to view events in a positive light
column23: to generate optimism.  It produces energy and promotes morale.  It is easier to aim high and expect to reach the target."  (P. 29)  "Overcoming obstacles
column24: leaping over hurdles
column25: and recovering from fumbles can strengthen a team that has the discipline not to panic under pressure." (P. 71)  "Once the 'loser' label gets slapped on
column26: those suffering losses are set up to fail.  They find it harder to get support
column27: harder to get opportunities." (P. 115)  "Various turnaround tasks operate on different clocks.  Bold strokes are fast and can be done by one powerful person; long marches to change culture and behavior take more time and the commitment of many people.  Execution is play by play
column28: game by game
column29: while strategy is season by season..." (P. 178)  "People embodying the pathologies of the past can always be replaced
column30: but eliminating the bad does not automatically produce the good.  It takes a major effort on the part of leaders to foster confidence that a demoralized company or group is capable of working together and succeeding at it.  Restoring people's (sic) confidence in one another requires four kinds of action..." (P. 241)  "Confidence is an expectation of a positive outcome
column31: but what happens when outcomes are negative?  The dividing line between winning streaks and losing streaks is the choice of behavior in response to setbacks...  That decision to build rather than retreat
column32: to rally rather than get discouraged
column33: involves viewing setbacks through an optimistic lens
column34: as an opportunity to learn and move on." (P. 357)  And it just goes on and on
column35: mercilessly and cluelessly.   The wisest
column36: most incisive business people read
column37: study and think about far more than just sports and business.  I would recommend Ms. Kanter first enroll in a decent freshman-level literature or history seminar.  There she can learn to write and
column38: with some effort on her part and perhaps a bit of luck
column39: to formulate some imaginative approaches to problem-solving.  Beyond this bilge
column40: I have had the good fortune to come across many books that have helped address confidence.  These are: selected essays by Montaigne and Emerson
column41: `Hamlet'
column42: Whitman's "Song Of Myself"
column43: David Herbert Donald's biography `Lincoln'
column44: `Emotional Intelligence'
column45: `Flow'
column46: and Jack Welch's `Winning'.  `Confidence' inspires confidence only in the realization that you (no matter who you are) are at least intelligent enough to be the "Ernest L. Arbuckle Professor" at Harvard Business School

column1: I have given Skinner's book I star
column2: because it was required to write a review. I consider its ideas dangerous - for the simple reason that it represents a frontal assault upon our ideas of freedom and human dignity.    Of course
column3: Skinner doesn't see anything 'sinister' in his ideas. He simply takes it for granted that our notion that we have 'interior selves' and are autonomous (i.e. free agents) - is largely an illusion. In short
column4: Skinner's argument (and it just that
column5: not a statement of fact
column6: as he would have us believe) - is that we are wholly determined in our lives by environmental factors
column7: which is to say - 'conditioned' by forces outside ourselves.    Skinner's argument
column8: then
column9: is that we might as well accept this and make the most of it. Rather than resisting the idea of conditioning
column10: he thinks we should perfect it. In short
column11: if there is nothing more than external conditioning and learned behaviour
column12: then we might as well have social scientists maximising our potential to live with the learned behaviour.    The fallacy of Skinner's argument
column13: is that the notion of human freedom and dignity rests upon scientifically 'unprovable' or 'unverifiable' assertions. When we look
column14: we cannot find a 'ghost in the machine' - and thus
column15: we might as well accept the machine. But it is a facile argument. The fact that we cannot reduce our interior selves to a scientifically quantifiable formula
column16: is the very reason why it remains of vital importance to human life. Its resistence to reductive
column17: strictly empirical formulas
column18: is what makes human nature special. Nobody sensible would deny that childhood experience is highly formative
column19: or that certain genetic determinants are at work
column20: or that empirically speaking
column21: we are conditioned in our external lives. But we have no reason to suppose that these factors are ALL determining.    Needless to say
column22: Skinner's thinking was informed by wholly secular ideas of social and scientific progress - much as if we could get behind everything and 'push.' Paradoxically
column23: Skinner never gave that much thought to who controls the controllers! Skinner wasn't thinking of anything like Soviet style dialectical materialism - but
column24: if we wanted a graphic example of how things go painfully wrong by regimenting human nature and trying to educate people out of the idea that they have 'interior selves' - well
column25: the failures of the Soviet Union (or Communist China) tell us all we need to know.    I don't say this with any illusions that captalism and 'free markets' per se
column26: are intrinsically more respectful of human freedom and dignity. Those values hinge upon something deeper
column27: and without that
column28: there is little to prevent a 'market oriented' society drifting into social controls and abuses of human nature
column29: no less than those which drove the Soviet system.      Ironically
column30: some reviewers have adduced Buddhist teachings(i.e. the doctrine of anatman = no-self) as further confirmation of Skinner's ideas. But Buddhism only denies that there is a permanent self in the skandhas or aggregates - a materialistic self. In fact
column31: the Buddha taught people to take refuge in the 'self' and the Dharma as an inner lamp. Buddhists do have 'interior' lives. Moreover
column32: the Buddha accorded 'dignity' to human nature
column33: or manusya- as the 'most noble of two footed beings.'    It is not anyone else's business to define what we are - in any final or absolute sense. Those who would endeavour to do so are of the same mind as those who would patent the human genome
column34: and plan on engineering an improved version of the human race in their laboratories. The chances are that those who would play 'God' will end up doing the devil (or Mara's) work. As the Rolling Stones song said: - "Hey - you! Get offa maa cloud! "

column1: Listening to Gieseking play Debussy is like listening to a pianist who sat at his instrument with the composer's score stripped of all dynamic markings and performance instructions and interpreted what he saw like it were Beethoven. There are crescendos where there shouldn't be crescendos and violent and sharply biting outbursts in passages where Debussy is asking of the pianist the most gentle and delicate touch possible. I'm not saying Gieseking isn't a phenomenal pianist from a technical standpoint
column2: but he displays so little regard for the composer's intentions. By all means
column3: buy this record if you want to hear Gieseking
column4: but not if you want to hear Debussy

column1: ROBOT MONSTER is one of "those" classic Five Star One Star '50s horror movies. The problem with "C" movies is that they can't be rated by the usual standards. By its own standards its a gem.   But for the fact that this gobbler wasn't touched by Ed Wood it has all the guaranteed elements of bad moviemaking. Actually
column2: ROBOT MONSTER was panned so severely upon release that director Phil Tucker attempted suicide afterward.  ROBOT MONSTER concerns the depredations of a fat gorilla-suited space alien in a diving helmet (Ro-Man from the planet Ro-Man which is populated by the race of Ro-Mans) who comes to earth and destroys virtually all of human life with the aid of a vacuum tube radio and a Lawrence Welk bubble machine.  Ro-Man is a grouchy
column3: slow moving space visitor who talks with his hands and grumbles a lot. He lives in one of the more familiar Hollywood caves of Bronson Canyon
column4: California.   The few surviving humans (a family of five) protect themselves by stringing aluminum foil around their house so that Ro-Man cannot use his death ray machine against them. Instead
column5: he must dispose of them one at a time "by the process of strang-u-laaa-tion" if they are so foolish as to step outside of their Reynolds Wrap safety zone.    Given their current world political situation
column6: the humans
column7: Richard Nixon-like
column8: are seeking "Peace---But peace with honor!" from Ro-Man. Hmmm. Seems reasonable. After all
column9: Ro-Man has really shown restraint up until this point. Why shouldn't they trust him?    But wait! Even after atomizing everybody else (apparently including the film's scriptwriter) Ro-Man has developed a penchant for Alice
column10: the eldest daughter of the survivors. Fortunately for us
column11: Alice seems to have a corresponding yen for excessively hirsute and overweight men wearing fishbowls on their heads. So while Ro-Man is distracted picking a bouquet for his new girlfriend
column12: the family figures out a way to finally finish him off.    Exactly how humanity is going to repopulate the earth with only the Father Knows Best kids around escapes me
column13: but clearly someone involved with this film escaped from somewhere.  It's as bad and as much fun as it sounds.

column1: Before you vote this review down
column2: I ask that you fully read it
column3: so you can understand why Sin City does not function as a good film.  Sin City unfortunately is an absolute mess.  I sat down to watch this provocative disaster about a year ago
column4: and it has stuck with me ever since.  It has lingered for so long because it is representative of everything that could possibly go wrong with a production such as this.  I am fan of Robert Rodriguez's directing. I also absolutely love everything that Quentin Tarantino has cranked out since his inception as a director.  I grew up with interest in the occasional Frank Miller graphic novel.  This is why it is so sad that Sin City fails on so many levels.  Within the first 23 minutes of watching this film
column5: I was praying that it would be over soon.  I only stuck it out so I could one day write this review.  Let's break it down to its most basic levels.  The film has great directors
column6: great actors
column7: a great story
column8: and a great production design.  With all of this going for it
column9: one expects "Sin City" to be a landmark movie experience
column10: and it is -- though
column11: for me
column12: the experience is a negative one
column13: and the attainment it achieves is in the depths of pointless
column14: mean-spirited exploitation.  The film tells three stories (with a fourth vignette as a framing device): Bruce Willis battling a child-molesting monster; Mickey Rourke as an ugly hulk out to avenge a girlfriend's murder; and Clive Owen as a private eye helping a band of imperiled hookers.  The three segments transpire more or less in sequence (with some confusing overlapping) and all take place in Sin City: a super-corrupt
column15: super-violent
column16: super-shadowy
column17: and in every other way super-exaggerated caricature of a '40s Hollywood film-noir world.  It's a caricature of a caricature.  No one would ever confuse this world with reality. The heroes shake off multiple gunshot wounds
column18: devastating blows to the head and other lethal overtures like slaps on the cheek; the hookers all look like Victoria's Secret models; the scenes are ugly day dreams.  And
column19: to be fair
column20: the stylish blend of CGI- exoticism and continual chaos generates a certain visual fascination. Sin City
column21: however
column22: can't sustain it
column23: and after the first segment it's hard to imagine how anyone could find its trashy excess anything but tedious
column24: obnoxious
column25: and repetitive.  Everything that happens in the movie is an calculated cliche. The stories have a minimal narrative drive or interest
column26: the banter is banal pseudo-Raymond-Chandler babble and the performances are as shallow as most "SNL" skits these days.  Rodriguez is rather vain because of his pride in the way his movie so faithfully bows to the "genius" of Miller and re-creates his comic-book world with the same kind of religious devotion Gus Van Sant paid to Hitchcock with his frame-for-frame "Psycho" remake.  Is comic-book art some special invention that deserves such recognition? Aren't movies already enough like dumb comic books without actually trying to BE one?  Though it's not immediately obvious
column27: "Sin City" is a comedy
column28: and its aspiration is to pull off the Tarantino trick of making its audience wearily laugh at the outrageousness of its sadism at the same time it subtly gets off on it sexually.  And it's out to one-up Tarantino by basking in the pornography of brutality on a large scale
column29: a giddy spectacular in which we sit back like Romans at the Coliseum watching people being decapitated
column30: disemboweled
column31: dismembered
column32: castrated and humiliated.  Check out Fellini's Satyricon if that is what you are really after.  The publicity has made a big deal about what a "risky" commercial venture this is
column33: and how heroic it was for Rodriguez to insist on putting Miller's name in the title and above his own in the directing credits. But this all stinks of the worst Hollywood insincerity.  For one thing
column34: can anyone doubt that such a violent
column35: low-budget movie with such a lineup of stars will make a ton of money? Given the distance "Sin City" pushes the envelope to on sick movie violence
column36: and given the recent Columbine-like massacres
column37: such a backlash from the Christian right and other voices for movie censorship seems likely (and Rodriguez may even be hoping for it).  I don't support these voices for a minute: I don't believe in censorship and I don't think movies motivate mass murder. But I do think that a film like this
column38: especially one made by a major director under the flag of artistic integrity
column39: adds something ugly to the air for which critics must hold it accountable.  Sitting through the thing
column40: watching scene after scene in which I was being asked to be entertained by the spectacle of helpless people being tortured
column41: I kept thinking of all the other horrible acts that are being committed today and how we
column42: as an American society are taught to think that it is all so gruesome and atrocious.  I suppose some people don't find it that bad. "Sin City" is their movie.

column4: no tables of settings and types.  Just paragraph after paragraph of "if you notice this
column5: try that".  In my mind this should be called something like the "Jeff Foxworthy you might be a redneck PC repair tech manual". However
column6: if you are new to PC repair and have no idea where to start looking for the resolution of a problem
column7: this MIGHT be just the book you need - because you can sit and thumb through it and look like you are doing something useful while you await the arrival of the guy who knows what he's doing.  You might even stumble on an antidote that actually applies to the problem you are currently experiencing

column1: My reaction to this book was the eventual impetus to just go out and purchase other books on meditation because the style and approach of the author were so irksome to me. I bought it because of the simple eloquence of the cover and the title
column2: and I think I did read the first page when I was in the store. It looked straightforward
column3: and I did indeed want to learn simply "how to meditate"
column4: being a beginner. (I subsequently learned that there are actually a few books called "how to meditate".)   I felt it was important to write a review because there seem to be so many positive ones
column5: and it seems a book that may work for some
column6: but for some like me
column7: it's a real turn-off
column8: although fortunately for me I just resolved to look for other meditation books (I've been using the "Getting in the Gap" meditation most extensively
column9: and been trying to read a couple other books). There are a few reasons I wanted to learn how to meditate... one of them being the hope of maybe experiencing moments of deep insight or contact with something mystical or angelic
column10: and at one point the author actually more or less actually discourages this aspect of meditation. He specifically refers to the possibility of these types of experiences during meditation
column11: saying that you can just basically ignore it and keep going with the meditation
column12: because these aren't the important part of meditation. It would seem to me if you had a mystical experience during meditation it would be something important enough to pay attention to
column13: whether "real" or not.   This annoyed me
column14: but my disagreement with that view was not so much the problem
column15: as the consistent authoritarian and absolute style of his teachings on meditation. He seemed so focused on the shoulds and shouldn'ts of the whole discipline
column16: which to me in a way is sort of going against the whole notion of meditation
column17: and it made me put the book down. I did his first breathing exercise
column18: which was fine
column19: and I tried to go on with the book
column20: but the style of his teaching was too much for me. It was annoying because the cover looks so elegant and zen-like and then what was inside
column21: to me
column22: seemed at odds with that.   Basically
column23: if an an air of finality in an instructive book on meditation doesn't appeal to you
column24: then you may want to read-before-you-buy. Because of my frustration with it
column25: I was only able to get 15 pages or so into it
column26: so I can't say much to the teachings of the book
column27: only the way in which it was presented

column1: While I realize that many readers enjoy approaching a topic through the author's personal experiences
column2: people like myself will find much of this book self indulgent.    	Other parts of the book deal with the things like the adoption community (see the Families With Children From China website instead)
column3: and the single child policy.    As a long time member of  Zero Population Growth I can hardy be impartial on the latter
column4: but why spend an entire chapter on the single child policy if later on you are going to say that gender ratios in India are even worse?   	 	I expect that one of the target audiences for this book is parents deciding whether or not to adopt from China.  While I myself would strongly recommend it
column5: I am also one of the parents the book mentions for whom the lack of identifiable birth parents was a major selling point.  Of course
column6: many adoptive parents have the opposite desire
column7: and perhaps they might consider places like Korea or Guatemala (Obviously domestic would be even better for those adoptive parents
column8: but it might be considered impossible).    My Korean niece and nephew know what city their biological parents are from
column9: their occupation and why they were given up for adoption. They could probably find their biological parents very easily if they ever chose to (They are in their teens and have no desire to do so as of yet in spite of their parents urging).   Under Guatemalan law the birth mother must remain in contact through the entire adoption process
column10: signing off multiple times
column11: including at the end of the process.    I read of one couple who suffered the heartbreak of a delay because the woman who claimed to be the birth mother failed the blood test so the child was not eligible for adoption.  	With this in mind
column12: the place where this book and I part company is in approaching an adopted child when all you have to go on is one sentence in an adoption report.  I strongly agree with the expert who is quoted in the book as saying "Tell your daughter the truth.  Tell her you don't know where she comes from."  as well as the author's friend who says "I think there is not the looking inward in China that you imagine".   Therefore I wince when the author says about an imaginary conversation with the birth mother that "I imagine this partly out of my own projection and wishful thinking
column13: I know.  I want my daughter to have been wanted." Or that "You have to assume that love was involved."  The vast majority of adoption literature that we have received specifically says not to tell your child that the biological parents loved them.  Even the literature that does recommend  telling  the child that the biological parents loved them then goes on to urge you not to tell your child that giving them up for adoption was an act of love
column14: as love then becomes equated with abandonment.  One psychiatrist was quoted as saying that many of his clients are in therapy because of such statements.   This book never explicitly encourages such statements
column15: but I expect that many readers would take it this way.   				------------------Ed 						Tianan

column2: because the word has been misused
column3: purposely
column4: to give darker skinned peoples an exotic barbarity. The word simply means school and is used
column5: worldwide
column6: to refer to schools both secular and religious
column7: simply coming from the Arabic root "to study."    I do not understand why Manji rants and raves over and over about ijtihad  (reasoning independent of the past religious opinions)
column8: but one thing is for sure
column9: and that is that she has no knowledge of Muslim movements of the 18th centuries onwards.  One of the most successful movements
column10: founded by Muhammad ibn Abdul Wahhab
column11: known as Wahhabism by those opposed to it or Salafism by its proponents
column12: has as its founding principle the use of ijtihad
column13: as it wished to break from what it considered was corruption of Islam by all Islamic groups and empires after the community of the Prophet.   However
column14: ibn Abdul Wahhab's followers had to change his theories
column15: as he only accepted the Qur'an and Sunna (the traditions of the prophet)
column16: but these traditions were not collected with any authority until the 9th century
column17: meaning in order to claim the Sunna
column18: the Wahhabi's would have to accept the consensus of the first 3 centuries of Islam (which includes the Golden Age).  The problem with the Wahhabi's is that they are a exceptionally right wing
column19: and so their independent analysis (ijtihad) is inherently conservative.  Why doesn't Manji know this.  It is not a hidden fact.  She doesn't even need to learn Arabic to find this out
column20: it is written plainly for anyone with knowledge of English.  You don't need a comprehensive study of Islam to know this
column21: though you would think it should be a prerequisite for anyone claiming to have the ability to tell the world of the trouble with Islam

column1: As someone interested in the Russian Revolution
column2: I found this book at a school library and read it. I was not favorably impressed. Lenin is pushed down to the level of megalomaniac idiot. You don't have to like the guy to try to really explain his motivations or to seek real answers to the questions that bamboozle people. In addition to the pyscho-babble mentioned by other reviewers
column3: I had a problem with Robert Service picking on someone who is to dead to sue him for slander. Robert Service accuses Lenin of shooting down his own Soviet troops (an absolute idiocy in the middle of a civil war).It may be fashionable to produce "exposes" of Soviet leaders
column4: but that doesn't make it a good trend. Modern biographers of the Russian revolutionaries need to remember that Joe McCarthy and his Committee are no longer here to black-list them. In Robert Service's biography
column5: I was upset to find the author judging Lenin through 21st century glasses. By this I mean: 1. Cutting out the context of the Russian economy's ruin during the Civil War. 2. The abject failures of the "democrats"  3. Forgetting what the alternatives would have been had the opposition won (I don't mean the Whites- even the peasants hated them) I wonder what Mr. Service would do if he were in Lenin's shoes...  While I'm wondering
column6: I think I'll go pick up W. Bruce Lincoln's books on how the revolution happened and what happened during and after the civil war

column1: I'm not sure about the glowing reviews here
column2: but I fail to see how this book can be much help to current embedded designers? While the copyright is 2004
column3: most of the book reads as if it was written in 1994 or even earlier. The book talks a lot about discrete logic
column4: something that's rarely (or barely) used in modern embedded designs. Likewise
column5: the author largely assumes external memory
column6: which is also increasingly rare.   Most people
column7: today
column8: use SPI
column9: I2C and/or CAN serial interfaces within (and even between) embedded devices and peripherals. The book doesn't provide useful coverage of any of these (or even mention some of them). It's as if the author's last real world embedded development work was with the 8051 a few decades ago? It's the only processor he goes into any detail on and not even the current System on a Chip versions.  The book does contain a useful primer to basic electronics and microcontroller theory. But like the rest of the book
column10: much of it is out of date relatively to current embedded design and the same material is covered much better in other books.   The only reason to POSSIBLY buy this book
column11: in my opinion
column12: is the chapter on worst case timing and loading analysis. But even that section is showing its age. Signal levels
column13: PC board design
column14: bus/signal termination
column15: impedance matching techniques
column16: etc. are largely done differently today than what the author suggests. For example
column17: do you know anyone using TTL discrete logic in their current embedded designs? Apparently both Ken Arnold and Newnes/Elsivier think someone does? You can have my copy back Amazon

column1: Time was when the words Betty Crocker actually stood for something good in cookbooks
column2: although the books' recipes
column3: for better or for worse
column4: were always a product of their times.  The very first "Betty Crocker Picture Cook Book" was published in 1950 (still available)
column5: revolutionized how cookbooks were produced
column6: and was an enormous best-seller.  The recipes were the result of much thorough testing in the company's kitchens and in homes across America.  This was cooking from scratch with very little reliance on convenience foods in its pages.  This gradually changed as Betty and her books became more and more of a shill for General Mills' products and her name got plastered on one mix after another to the benefit of the company's bottom line
column7: but to the detriment of good cooking.    The two all-purpose cookbooks that came out in 1961 and 1969 were both loaded with recipes and wonderful tips/helps
column8: although you could see the beginnings of sacrificing quality for convenience--especially in the 1969 edition--but this was still relatively minor in proportion to the majority of the recipes.  If you have one of these books
column9: treasure and keep it; you'll never see their likes again.  The current 10th edition looks good but
column10: like the past several editions
column11: the number of recipes has been drastically reduced.  Gone are the many variations
column12: which are especially missed in baked goods.  It was wonderful having recipes of many cakes that were sized for two people or small families and having different mixing methods to choose from.  Now way too many recipes are of the "dump and stir" method instead of choosing methods that would insure the best results.  Also gone is the very friendly
column13: assuring
column14: conversationial voice of yesteryear.  Yes
column15: there are recipes covering a wider range of ingredients and styles
column16: but they are mostly stripped-down versions.    It's obvious that the folks at Betty Crocker now seem to think that no one really cooks anymore and can't be bothered with proper preparation of dishes
column17: which begs the question of why General Mills even bothers to publish these cookbooks anymore.  The "Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook" is a better bet for those looking for an all-purpose
column18: everyday guide.  It has a better layout
column19: the recipes and ingredients are generally of a higher quality
column20: and there are more recipes and variations than Betty Crocker's had in some time.  Even better
column21: if you care at all about the quality of the food you eat and serve your family
column22: I highly recommend the cookbooks of Cooks' Illustrated/America's Test Kitchen.  Their comparable
column23: general-purpose cookbook is called "The America's Test Kitchen Family Cookbook."  The recipes are tested and reworked--dozens of times
column24: if necessary--to be the best their staff can make them and you get precise directions in preparing them.  It's a shame that Betty Crocker has abdicated her throne and good name
column25: but there's even better stuff out there now.  Go for it!

column1: I have read just about every trading
column2: stock scandal
column3: biography type book and this was probably the worst book I've ever read.    As far as Kessler as a writer
column4: he is decent.  The stories were told nicely but the content is what disturbs me.  This was the first book I've read of this type concerning analysts.  I am very familar with analysts and how they work and have done some analyst work myself.  This book justifies to me why analyst are the most worthless people on wall street and how investment banking has ruined the true
column5: real analysts similar to how Kessler described himself in the early years.  Now to the stories.  Lets just say that analyst are no traders and shouldn't even be hanging out with them.  Kessler's "wild" tales sound more like a frat house than a Wall Street war room.  $4000 dinner?  Big deal.  Almost got into a fight?  Whew
column6: that was a close one Andy.  What disturbes me the most is how he never talks numbers.  So and so did this deal and so and so got paid for this.  How much?  Why should I be excited that you donated 6 months of your life and earned 200K airline miles if you're not going to tell me how much you and/or your associates earned?  Most of the deals he participates in he doesn't see a dime from.  What the hell?  So you devote your time and life to kiss butt in anticipation of getting a bone.  The only good thing he did is get out and go to the buy-side of the business.  Kessler spends countless chapters relating stories of traders and other Wall Street bankers that were busted and thrown in jail for this and that
column7: but he tells them in passing as if he read them in the Wall Street Journal instead of getting the inside scoop.    Perhaps the worst story of Kessler's is his supposed encounter with the infamous Nick Leeson of Barings Bank in a Hong Kong bar.  He claims he will never know if it was Nick but it couldn've been.  Great.  So he could've encountered an infamous trader who did way more wild stuff than him but he is not sure it was the right guy.  Let me help you out.  It was not Nick Leeson.  First of all Nick Leeson never traded bonds as you claim the man was a bond trader.  Secondly
column8: the encounter took place in 1990 and even if he had been trading bonds
column9: Leeson was not trading in Asia until the early to mid 90s.  Great story by the way.  Basically this book illegitimizes the analyst business and proves to me how boring and worthless those people are.  I would advise to read this book only if you are interested in falling asleep.

column1: I was very pleased to finally acquire this book
column2: having heard of it several years ago. Although I'm not an expert in history
column3: I have read a lot of books concerning this period
column4: and always look forward to reading more. My pleasure soon turned to dismay as I started reading. Through the first few chapters I had a growing but unspecific feeling of unease - something about the prose didn't ring true. It was nothing I could put my finger on; aspects of the writing didn't feel authentic.  I persevered. Eventually I stumbled across details that I knew were wrong. For instance
column5: in this period the term "Your Majesty" to address the King or Queen had not yet been introduced. This didn't come about until the time of the Tudors. Plantagenet monarchs were content to be addressed as "Your Grace". Next
column6: Edward IV was several times described as wearing a collar of interlinked S's. Unlikely. Yorkist collars tended to consist of roses and suns - the interlinked S collars were favoured by the Lancastrian nobility. Then in book 2 of the series we were asked to believe there was a Jewish money-lender in Whitby. As this story is set slap bang in the middle of the three hundred and fifty year period during which all Jews were banned from England
column7: I find this hard to believe. Book 3 (which I've read
column8: living as I do outside the US) would have us believe a crescent moon sailed the sky for an entire night. I ask "On which planet?!" A crescent moon when new is seen only at the start of the night
column9: and when waning is only seen in the hours before dawn. The only moon that is seen all night is a full moon.  These known inaccuracies ruined the book for me. I found myself questioning every detail I read. Was it true? Was it authentic? Or was it just a flight of fancy or wishful thinking on behalf of the author? In the end I was unable to finish the 3rd book in the series because I found myself irritated to the point that I no longer cared about the fates of the characters. I'm only grateful that I got the books out of the library rather than spending hard earned cash on them.   I'm left wondering how such glaring errors could make their way into a published book...or am I expecting too much that a work of historical fiction should reflect its setting accurately

column1: The reason many of us fail to succeed is that we buy into common sense.  This book does just that by reinforcing bad practices.  It suggests that one should save and invest wisely.  There is little way in which a person could achieve significant wealth by this method though perhaps a good retirement.  The most successful people do not follow this method.  I am pretty well off myself and I can say I did not follow this method and had I
column2: I would not be doing so well.  Unfortunately there is not a solid path to wealth (not that I know of).  Compare the wealth of Richard Branson versus Donald Trump - two very different approaches without few similarities.  My mother followed this approach and ended with just a small savings.  The story sounds appealing until you realize that it is fiction - there was no such man and that should speak for itself.

column1: Meandering
column2: amateurish writing with no conflict.  Please save yourself the time of reading this unsatisfying book.  I kept hoping that all the ideas that were introduced would be developed and paid off
column3: but they never were.  as I got later and later in the book
column4: I thought perhaps there was a big surprise ending
column5: but it never arrives!  Lots of interesting storylines are started - is there intelligent life on the new planet?  Will the starship stay and come into conflict with the native population?  Will the legions of sleeping crew awaken?  Will any of the crew abandon their mission
column6: or natives stow away on the ship?  Will either betrayed lover freak and do something?  Will the VOLCANO go off for christ's sake???  Nothing happens!!! The book stomps all over Chekhov's cardinal rule of drama - if you put a shotgun on the wall in the first act
column7: it damn well better go off in the third.  There are shotguns everywhere in this book but they remain dusty relics that add nothing but frustration to the experience of the reader.  The love story is laughably dry

The author and most of the readers are missing the boat.  "Jesus Christ" was never a real person.  He is a mythological character
column2: invented in the 2nd Century by members of secret societies and mystery schools that stretched from Egypt to China
column3: practicing a mythological-religious tradition that had existed for thousands of years.  This is what accounts for the widespread myth of Jesus in the ancient world
column4: plus remarkable similarities between the life and teachings of Jesus
column5: Buddha

column1: I have read this book (and its companion volume) a couple of times
column2: and to be honest I am not a fan.  Many of Jan Fennell's suggestions are useful
column3: but none are original.   Ms Fennell's method is based on the idea of using the non-violent language of the wolf pack to put your dog in his rightful subordinate place
column4: and therefore gain his understanding and cooperation.  Alpha wolves eat first - so Ms Fennell has the dog owner eat dinner before his dog.  Alpha wolves take the pack out hunting - so we are bid to walk our dogs daily.  Alpha wolves aren't demonstrative - so we are told to ignore our dogs for five minutes each time we arrive home from work.  These suggestions are sensible
column5: but they are hardly revolutionary.  Maintaining dominant status by behaving like an "alpha" wolf is a technique that has been championed by many other authors - the only difference is that Ms Fennell gives this process the cutesy name of "Amichien bonding".  The technique is a good one for restoring a relationship with a dog that has been spoiled or confused in the past by weak or misinformed owners. Its success lies not only in the owner mimicking canine behaviour
column6: but also in the institution of house rules and a predictable daily routine for the dog.    So what is wrong with this book?  The first fatal flaw is the unrealistic simplicity of the method.  Ms Fennell seems to believe that all canine behavioural problems are caused by the dog wishing to be alpha.  It is certainly true that a dog with a misplaced sense of his own importance will probably become a problem dog.  However
column7: dogs can also behave badly for a plethora of other reasons - poor training
column8: learned fear
column9: boredom
column10: health issues
column11: confusion and inherent high prey drive
column12: to name just a few.  Ms Fennell's insistence that all canine problems are dominance problems that can be cured by "Amichien bonding" is unfortunately just not realistic.       For a professional dog trainer
column13: Ms Fennel also displays a rather disturbing lack of knowledge about several dog breeds.  At one point she states that it may be impossible to fully train Bull Terriers "and dogs of this type" due to their inherent "savage natures"!  One gets the impression that she has been unable to train this type of dog herself and holds a grudge about it.  Whatever the reason
column14: I find it somewhat disingenuous of her to ignore the fact that other trainers have managed to train these breeds to very high standards
column15: and blame her own failure to do so on the dogs instead of on her own methods.  In short?  If you know very little about dog behaviour and have a mildly pushy dog
column16: then this book isn't a bad buy.  Certainly
column17: applying the "Amichien bonding" advice won't hurt.  It is the same type of programme as recommended by dog behaviourists the world over (you can get much of the same information for free on the internet
column18: from Shirley Chong's website for example).    However
column19: Ms Fennell's book is not a comprehensive guide to solving every dog's problems.  If your dog has moderate to serious behavioural problems
column20: save your money and book a consultation with a professional behaviourist.  Your dog will thank you for it.
